IN THE FAMILY COURT OF THE ___________ CIRCUIT
CO-PARENTING PLAN: AGREEMENT REGARDING CHILD CUSTODY, TIMESHARING, AND SUPPORT
, by and between PARENT A and PARENT B (collectively hereinafter referred to as â€œParentsâ€) and applies to the Child(ren) named below in Paragraph 3.00.
WHEREAS, Parents wish to effectuate a preliminary settlement of all matters relating to their minor Child(ren);
WHEREAS, parents intend to seek approval of their Agreement from the Family Court of the ____________ Circuit of the State of ____________ hereinafter referred to as the â€œFamily Courtâ€;

WHEREAS, Parents intend this to be a binding agreement between them to govern the co-parenting of their Child(ren) but do not plan to seek approval of their Agreement from the Family Court of their jurisdiction.

Children of separated Parents do best in both the short term and the long run when they feel loved and cared for by both Parents. We recognize that this requires that we cooperate, and that we each support our Child(ren) having a good relationship with the other Parent.
We are both responsible for and will contribute to the care and upbringing of our Child(ren).
Our Child(ren) have the right to love and be loved by both Parents, without feeling guilt or disapproval.
We agree that we will make decisions that are in the best interests of our Child(ren) and will put their interests ahead of our own.

We will find an appropriate way to consider our Child(ren)â€™s views in making our decisions, provided however, that our Child(ren) should never be put in the position of having to â€œchooseâ€ between Parents. They love both of us and have a right to meaningful and regular contact with both Parents and their extended families unless there are safety issues.
We will make it clear to our Child(ren) that although we're asking for their input, they're not responsible for the decisions or final plans. We are responsible for making these decisions.

Our Child(ren) and the other Parent should know well in advance about important changes that will affect them, such as if one Parent is planning to relocate or have a new partner move into their home.
We will keep our Child(ren) out of our conflict. We will not ask them to pick sides, carry messages, or hear our possible complaints about the other Parent.

We agree that we will communicate in a civil manner with each other, and we will not argue in front of the Child(ren) or involve them in any conflict between us. We will each encourage our Child(ren) to respect the other parent.

We agree that we will first seek services from mental health professional(s), subject matter experts, and mediators or arbitrators to assist us in decision-making and parenting our Child(ren), rather than file legal requests for relief with the Family Court.

We will both promote our Child(ren)'s relationship with the other Parent. We will not speak negatively about the other Parent in the presence of the Child(ren), and we will encourage our Child(ren) to spend time with their siblings, the other Parent, and their extended family. We will discourage family members and friends from speaking negatively about the other Parent in the presence of the Child(ren).
We will exchange educational, medical, and extra-curricular information about our Child(ren).
We recognize the importance of exchanging contact information (Parents' address, telephone numbers, email address), so we can communicate and know about our Child(ren).
We recognize that new intimate relationships for either Parent may impact our Child(ren). We agree that we will carefully consider how to introduce any new partners and possible
We will communicate with to the other Parent before there is significant involvement of a new partner in the lives of our Child(ren) (
a vacation with a new partner, cohabitation, remarriage, a pregnancy

We understand that this requirement is reciprocal and that both Parents have an affirmative responsibility to inform the other Parent in advance of informing the Child(ren) of any significant involvement of a new partner in the lives of our Child(ren).
Both Parents recognize that they can do much to minimize any possible negative impact of their divorce or separation on the Child(ren).
Each parent desires to remain responsible and active in promoting the
â€™s growth and development consistent with their best interests.Â
To this end, each of the Parents agree that they will always support the Child(ren) in having the best possible relationship with the other Parent.
Both Parents shall make a sincere effort to maintain open, ongoing communications concerning the
â€™s development, needs, and interests.Â Each Parent agrees to honor one another's parenting style, privacy, and authority.Â
Neither Parent shall engage in, nor permit or encourage any

, fiancÃ©e, significant other, grandparent, other relative or other associate, to criticize, disparage, demand, insult, or otherwise â€œbad-mouthâ€ the other parent, step-parent, significant other, or grandparent to the Child(ren) or in the presence or hearing of the Child(ren). This prohibition shall apply even to information that is truthful and accurate.

Neither Parent shall disparage, denigrate, make morally judgmental comments about, or belittle the other Parent in the Child(ren)â€™s presence, or allow them to be in the presence of people who do so.Â
Neither Parent shall fight (verbally for physical) in person or by telephone â€“ in the presence or hearing of the Child(ren).

Neither Parent shall align or attempt to align the Child(ren) against the other Parent (or relative), nor allow or encourage anyone else (including relative and friends) to do so. Neither Parent shall directly or indirectly ask the Child(ren) to choose between Parents, to choose to reside with one Parent instead of the other, or choose one household over the other household.

It is not intended that the Child(ren) become conduits for the Parentsâ€™ communication between each other, and the Parents shall be prohibited from asking the Child(ren) to convey any communication on behalf of one of them to the other. Neither Parent shall ask the Child(ren) to pass orders or instructions or uncomplimentary messages to the other Parent (orally or in writing). Complimentary messages are allowed and encouraged.

Neither Parent shall ask the Child(ren) to â€œkeep secretsâ€ from the other Parent or ask or encourage the Child(ren) to lie to the other Parent about events or persons the Child(ren) experienced during the visit with the other Parent, grandparent or relative.

Neither Parent shall ask the Child(ren) to â€œspy onâ€ the other Parent or the other Parentâ€™s lifestyle or household nor ask any detailed, â€œprobingâ€ questions about the other Parent or lifestyle or household of the other Parent.

Parents shall make every reasonable effort to foster feelings of affection between the Child(ren) and each Parent, recognizing that frequent and continuing association and communication of both Parents with the Child(ren) is in their best interests and welfare.Â

Both Parents shall encourage a positive parent-child relationship between the Child(ren) and the other Parent and shall not say or do anything (including â€œgrimaceâ€ or put on a â€œlong faceâ€) to adversely affect the Child(ren)â€™s love for the other Parent.

Neither Parent shall interfere with a parent-child relationship with the other Parent, and neither Parent shall conceal the Child(ren) from the other Parent during the other Parentâ€™s period of responsibility.
Parents shall always do whatever they reasonably can to ensure that there is as much consistency and continuity as possible in the
the Child(ren) receives guidance and nurturing in all areas of their lives.
PARENT Aâ€™s full legal name is ____________. Parent Aâ€™s residence address is ____________.
. Parent Bâ€™s full legal name is ____________. Parent Bâ€™s residence address is ____________.

. Legal custody is the authority to make major decisions involving the Child(ren).Â Such major decisions would include, among others, the decision to allow the Child(ren) to enter the armed forces, the decision to marry before the legal age, the decision to file a lawsuit, or accept a settlement of claims involving the Child(ren), the decision to allow the Child(ren) to use birth control, including pregnancy termination, the decision to allow the children to obtain a driverâ€™s license or passport, the decision to allow the Child(ren) to obtain substantial employment, the decision to authorize non-emergency medical or other treatment for the Child(ren), the decision to involve the Child(ren) in counseling, religious decisions affecting the Child(ren), major decisions involving the Child(ren)â€™s education, such as choice of school, change in school, advancement or retention, choice of curriculum, participation in extracurricular activities, and special education needs like tutoring, decisions as to the management of any substantial monies received by the Child(ren), decisions regarding major expenditures by or for the Child(ren), decisions involving serious discipline problems of the Child(ren), decisions involving the receipt, management and sale of real or personal property while a child is under
eighteen (18) years of age, and decisions involving a childâ€™s travel to any distance beyond the jurisdiction of the United States for any period of time.Â
LEGAL CUSTODY: JOINT TO BOTH PARENTS
. Parents shall share joint legal custody of the Child(ren) and shall make decisions together.

Parents agree they shall make significant decisions together and encourage input from Child(ren). If Parents cannot come to an agreement about a major decision, they shall use the dispute resolution process set out in this document.
LEGAL CUSTODY: SOLE TO ONE PARENT
. Parent A/B shall have sole legal custody of the Child(ren).
LEGAL CUSTODY: PARENTS MUST CONSULT BUT ONE PARENT HAS TIE-BREAKING AUTHORITY

. Parents shall share joint legal custody of the Child(ren), provided however, that if Parents cannot mutually agree on a legal custody decision for the Child(ren) after consulting with the other Parent and the Child(ren), then Parent A/B shall have tie-breaking authority to make the legal custody decision in the event of an impasse.
LEGAL CUSTODY: PARENTS MUST CONSULT BUT THERE IS A DIVISION OF AUTHORITY

Parents shall share joint legal custody of the Child(ren), provided however, that if Parents cannot mutually agree on a legal custody decision for the Child(ren), then Parent A shall have tie-breaking authority to make

major decisions about the Child(ren)'s education and extracurricular activities, after consulting with Parent B and the Child(ren) and Parent B shall have tie-breaking authority to make major decisions about the Child(ren)'s health care, language, and spirituality, after consulting with Parent A and the child.
LEGAL CUSTODY: ACCESS TO INFORMATION FOR PARENT WITHOUT LEGAL CUSTODY

. Although Parent A/B is awarded sole legal custody, Parent B/A shall have free and unrestricted access to all information pertaining to the Child(ren). The Parent who does not have legal custody may independently contact any provider serving the Child(ren) including education, health-related, extracurricular, etc. and access
with legal custody shall have an affirmative duty to inform the other Parent of any new providers working with the Child(ren).
LEGAL CUSTODY: EMERGENCY CONTACTS FOR THE CHILD(REN
. Both Parents shall be listed as the initial emergency contacts for the Child(ren) for any school, extracurricular
or other event where an emergency contact is requested.
LEGAL CUSTODY: EXPERT ADVICE WHEN MAKING LEGAL CUSTODY DECISIONS
Parents shall seek the advice and be guided by subject matter experts when making legal custody decisions on behalf of the Child(ren).

During the period when the Child(ren) is or are living with or in the care of a Parent, that Parent can make day-to-day decisions about our child, for example about, doing homework, meals, visiting with their friends, use of computer, etc.

In a health emergency for a Child, the Parent with care of the Child(ren) at that time will make the treatment decision, on the advice of medical personnel. If a Parent makes an emergency health decision for a Child, the Parent who has made the decision must immediately contact the other Parent.
LEGAL CUSTODY: HEALTH EMERGENCY OR DEATH OF OTHER PARENT

In the event of a Parentâ€™s medical emergency, the other Parent shall assume the major decision-making responsibilities for the Child(ren) until the situation becomes resolved. In the event of the death of one Parent, the other Parent shall care for the Child(ren), but the surviving Parent shall ensure that the Child(ren) has/have continued relations with the relatives of the deceased Parent.
Parents shall disengage from one another and make decisions independently when the Child(ren) is in their care.
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: GLOBAL PRIORITY

. If there is a conflict with different sections of the Physical Custody and Timesharing schedule, the governing hierarchy is from the highest to lowest as follows: (1) Holidays and Special Days; (2) Travel and Uninterrupted Time with the Child(ren); (3) Timesharing with the Child(ren) During School Breaks, and (4) Timesharing with the Child(ren) During the School Year.
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: TIMESHARING DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR

During the school year, parents agree to share time with their children as set forth hereinbelow. Understanding that each individual Childâ€™s developmental stage and needs should be the primary consideration for setting a schedule. Generally, younger children need more frequent transitions so they do not feel abandoned by either parent, while older children can tolerate longer absences. Each Childâ€™s health, education, special needs, and social, emotional, and physical well-being must be considered in selecting an appropriate schedule. Schedules may change over time by agreement of the Parents based on the Child(ren)â€™s needs. Below are suggested templates to be modified and based on each familyâ€™s needs.

. 50/50 schedules can benefit a Child because the Child spends substantial time living with both Parents. This allows the Child(ren) to build close relationships with both Parents and to feel cared for by both Parents. 50/50 schedules work best when:
to one another, so exchanges are easier;
communicate with each other about the Child(ren) without fighting;
Both Parents are committed to putting the Child(ren)â€™s best interests first;
Both Parents agree that the 50/50 schedule is best for their Child(ren).
Please note that exchange date can be adjusted to meet each familyâ€™s needs (
Parents exchange on Fridays after school as opposed to Monday)
. Please note that exchange date can be adjusted to meet each familyâ€™s needs (
Parents exchange on Fridays after school as opposed to Monday)
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: TIMESHARING DURING THE SCHOOL BREAKS

. Unless otherwise agreed by both Parents, school breaks shall be defined as beginning after school on the last day prior to the break and ending at the morning drop off at school on the day school resumes. During their designated school break time with the Child(ren), either Parent may elect to travel with the Child(ren) per the Travel with the Child(ren) provision hereinbelow.
The Parents shall share time with the Child(ren) during Fall Breaks as follows:

In odd years, Parent A shall have the Child(ren) during the first half of the break and Parent B shall have the Child(ren) during the second half of the break. In even years, Parent B shall have the Child(ren) during the first half of the break and Parent A shall have the Child(ren) during the second half of the break.
. In odd calendar years, Parent A shall have the entire break. In even calendar years, Parent B shall have the entire break.
CONTINUE SCHEDULE DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR
. Parents shall continue the normal during the school year schedule during this break.
. The Parents shall share time with the Child(ren) during Thanksgiving Breaks as follows:

. In odd years, Parent A shall have the Child(ren) during the first half of the break and Parent B shall have the Child(ren) during the second half of the break. In even years, Parent B shall have the Child(ren) during the first half of the break and Parent A shall have the Child(ren) during the second half of the break.
. In odd calendar years, Parent A shall have the entire break. In even calendar years, Parent B shall have the entire break.
. Notwithstanding the above, the Parent who does not have the Child(ren) on Thanksgiving Day shall have the right to spend time with the Child(ren) between 12 noon and 3pm on Thanksgiving Day.
CONTINUE SCHEDULE DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR
Parents shall continue the normal during the school year schedule during this break.
. The Parents shall share time with the Child(ren) during Winter Break as follows:

. In odd years, Parent A shall have the Child(ren) during the first half of the break, to include Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, and Parent B shall have the Child(ren) during the second half of the break, to include New Yearâ€™s Eve and New Yearâ€™s Day. In even years, Parent B shall have the Child(ren) during the first half of the break, to include Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, and Parent A shall have the Child(ren) during the second half of the break, to include New Yearâ€™s Eve and New Yearâ€™s Day.
In odd calendar years, Parent A shall have the entire break. In even calendar years, Parent B shall have the entire break.

In even years, Parent A shall have the first half of Winter Break to include Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, and Parent B shall have the second half to include New Yearâ€™s Eve and New Yearâ€™s Day. In odd years, Parent B shall have the first half of Winter Break to include Christmas Eve and Christmas Day and Parent A shall have the second half, to include New Yearâ€™s Eve and New Yearâ€™s Day. During their time, either parent may elect to travel with the Child(ren).

the custodial parent is not traveling, the non-custodial parent shall have the opportunity to spend time with the children on Christmas Day between ____am/pm and ____am/pm and New Yearâ€™s Day between ____am/pm and ____am/pm.
CONTINUE SCHEDULE DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR
. Parents shall continue the normal during the school year schedule during this break.
The Parents shall share time with the Child(ren) during Spring Breaks as follows:

In odd years, Parent A shall have the Child(ren) during the first half of the break and Parent B shall have the Child(ren) during the second half of the break. In even years, Parent B shall have the Child(ren) during the first half of the break and Parent A shall have the Child(ren) during the second half of the break.
. In odd calendar years, Parent A shall have the entire break. In even calendar years, Parent B shall have the entire break.
CONTINUE SCHEDULE DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR
Parents shall continue the normal during the school year schedule during this break.
. The Parents shall share time with the Child(ren) during Summer Break as follows:

. In odd years, Parent A shall have the Child(ren) during the first half of the break and Parent B shall have the Child(ren) during the second half of the break. In even years, Parent B shall have the Child(ren) during the first half of the break and Parent A shall have the Child(ren) during the second half of the break, to include New Yearâ€™s Eve and New Yearâ€™s Day.
CONTINUE SCHEDULE DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR
Parents shall continue the normal during the school year schedule during this break.
CONTINUE SCHEDULE DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR WITH OPTION FOR UNITERRUPTED TIME

. Parents shall continue the normal during the school year schedule during this break provided however that both parents shall have the option to take ___days/weeks of uninterrupted time with the Child(ren) every summer. Parents shall select and exchange their dates for uninterrupted time with the Child(ren) by no later than ____________(date) of the same year. In even years, Parent A shall have the first choice of dates for uninterrupted time during the Summer Break. In odd years, Parent B shall have the first choice of dates for uninterrupted time during the Summer Break.
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: HOLIDAYS AND SPECIAL DAYS
Parents agree that the following holidays shall be shared as follows:

. Parent A shall have the Child(ren) in even/odd years. Parent B shall have the Child(ren) in even/odd years. An alternated holiday/special day shall be defined as beginning at ___am/pm and ending at ___am/pm.

. Parent A shall have the Child(ren) for the first half and Parent B shall have the Child(ren) for the second half of this holiday/special day in even/odd years. Parent B shall have the Child(ren) for the first half and Parent A shall have the Child(ren) for the second half of this holiday/special day in even/odd years. A split holiday shall be defined as beginning at ___am/pm and ending at ___am/pm.
MONDAY/FRIDAY HOLIDAYS ATTACHED TO A WEEKEND
EVERY YEAR WITH PARENT A OR PARENT B
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: TRAVEL WITH THE CHILD(REN)
Each parent shall have the right to take up to ________ [insert days/weeks] days/weeks of
travel with the Child(ren) every year. The traveling parent shall provide ________ [insert number of days] daysâ€™ notice in writing to the non-traveling parent if the trip is outside of the State of
i. If the trip is within the State of

i, the traveling parent shall provide ________ [insert number of days] daysâ€™ notice in writing to the non-traveling parent. For out-of-state travel, at least ________ [insert number of days] days prior to departure (or ________ [insert number of days] days prior to departure for in-state travel), the traveling parent shall provide the non-traveling parent full details regarding the trip including: (a) airline; flight number; dates and times of each flight leg; (b) the dates and times the traveling parent and the Child(ren) will be staying in each hotel, residence, etc.; and (c) if the Child(ren) are going to be traveling with others, the names of the other travelers. If the traveling parent does not provide this information, the trip shall not occur.Â

Parents shall alternate having the first choice for dates for off-island travel during the Child(ren)â€™s summer vacations each year. In even years, Parent A shall have first choice for dates of travel so long as they provide those specific dates in writing to Parent B by no later than _________ [insert date] of that same year. In odd years, Parent B shall have first choice for dates of travel so long as they provide the specific dates in writing to Parent A by no later than _________ [insert date] of that same year. If either parent wishes to take the Child(ren) out of the country or miss any school days

travel, such a trip shall require the non-traveling parentâ€™s consent which, if such requests are occasional, shall not be unreasonably withheld. Parents agree that off-island travel shall not negatively impact the Child(ren)â€™s education.
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: RESCHEDULING AND MAKE-UP TIME
If a Parent is faced with an unexpected situation such as illness or a
death in the family, or an irregular event like a family wedding, the other Parent will make every effort to accommodate a request for a change in the
schedule. If the change in the schedule results in the Child(ren) missing considerable time with the accommodating parent, reasonable â€œmake-up timeâ€ will be arranged by the Parents.
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: RIGHT OF FIRST REFUSAL
We agree that if a Parent is unable to care for the Child(ren) themselves for a period of more than _______
hours during their time with the Child(ren), they shall notify the other Parent and give them the opportunity to spend the period for which childcare is required with the Child(ren).

If the non-custodial Parent cannot accommodate the request, the custodial Parent is responsible for arranging and paying for alternate childcare and will inform the other Parent of who will be caring for the Child(ren).
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: PICK-UP FOR NON-SCHOOL EXCHANGES

. If possible, exchanges shall occur at school provided however, that if exchanges are not during school pick-ups or drop offs, then the Parents receiving the Child(ren) for custodial time shall pick-up the Child(ren) from the other Parent.
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: DROP OFF FOR NON-SCHOOL EXCHANGES

. If possible, exchanges shall occur at school provided however, that if exchanges are not during school pick-ups or drop offs, then the Parents relinquishing the Child(ren) for custodial time shall drop off the Child(ren) to the other Parent.
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: EXCHANGES AT A NEUTRAL LOCATION
If possible, exchanges shall occur at school provided however, that if exchanges are not during school pick-ups or drop offs, Parents agree to exchange the child at the following neutral
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: PARENTAL AUTHORITY TO DELEGATE PICK-UP AND DROP OFF THE CHILD(REN
If it is not possible for

Parent A or Parent B to pick up or drop off the Child(ren) as provided for in the parenting time arrangement, the Parent who is responsible for the pick-up or drop off may delegate another person to pick up or drop off the Child(ren).
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: PERSONS AUTHORIZED TO PICK-UP AND DROP OFF THE CHILD(REN

If it is not possible for Parent A or Parent B to pick up or drop off the Child(ren) as provided for in the parenting time arrangement, the following people may pick up or drop off the Child(ren): ____________________________[insert names of all jointly authorized individuals].
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: CHILD(REN)â€™S PERSONAL BELONGINGS

Child(ren) often have favorite clothing, toys, or communication devices that they would like to have with them, wherever they are living. Even if these are gifts from one parent, it is normally appropriate to recognize the Child(ren)â€™s attachments and rights to personal property. If there is potential for conflict on this issue, it can be important to be clear about where the Child(ren) may take these items and communicate this directly to the other Parent.

Child(ren) may take personal items (for example, clothing, toys, sports equipment, cell phone, regardless of which Parent purchased these items), between the homes of Parent A and Parent B. Parents will not restrict the Child(ren)'s ability to take these items between homes. Parents will each have toiletries, pajamas and as many belongings as possible for the Child(ren) in their homes. These items will not travel back and forth.

If either Parent intends to relocate away from the island of their current residences or outside of the State where they currently reside, then the moving Parent shall provide the other Parent at least ______ (___) [insert number of days] daysâ€™ notice of their intent to move. After receiving notice of an intent to relocate, Parents shall meet and review this
Agreement Regarding Child Custody, Timesharing, and Support
to try to mutually agree on a modified plan they feel is in the best interests of the Child(ren).
an agreement, the Child(ren) shall remain with the non-moving parent until Parents are able to mutually agree or further order of the Court.
PHYSICAL CUSTODY AND TIMESHARING: MODIFICATION OF SCHEDULE BY AGREEMENT OF BOTH PARENTS

. While both Parents agree and intend that it is a priority to maintain stability and consistency in the life of their Child(ren), they understand that they have the power to modify the foregoing schedule at any time. Parents shall continue to work out the details of the Child(ren)â€™s schedules based on what is reasonable under the circumstances, mutually agreed to, and deemed in the best interest of the Child(ren). The foregoing schedule may be modified upon mutual agreement of the Parents in writing (text or e-mail is sufficient).

. Parents agree and understand that communication between Co-Parents is critical to their Child(ren)â€™s well-being. Parents shall work together to agree on what information needs to be communicated to the other Parent in a timely manner and, at a minimum agree, that the following shall be communicated:
A child will be spending the night somewhere other than the custodial parentâ€™s home.
A pet belonging to a child is missing, dying, or new.
An individual, other than the parent or subject child(ren), is moving into the custodial parentâ€™s home or property (includes long-term tenants).
An individual other than a parent is transporting a child (those authorized to transport the Child(ren) shall be agreed upon in advance in writing).
An individual other than a parent is caring a child when the custodial parent is not present (those authorized to care for the children shall be agreed upon in advance in writing).
Discipline of a child during one parentâ€™s timesharing day which may affect the other parentâ€™s timesharing.
. Parents shall communicate primarily through e-mail. The Parents may utilize text or telephone calls in

or in the event a timely response is needed (within 2 â€“ 4 hours). Otherwise, all communication shall be via e-mail. Both Parents shall check their e-mail at least once daily and shall respond to messages or other items needing attention (
switch requests) within 48 hours. If more time is needed to respond, the receiving parent shall acknowledge the message and provide a timeline in which a response shall be provided.
COMMUNICATION BETWEEN CO-PARENTS: E-MAIL AND TEXT ONLY
. Parents shall communicate primarily through e-mail and text. The Parents may utilize telephone calls in

or in the event a timely response is needed (within 2 â€“ 4 hours). Otherwise, all communication shall be via e-mail or text. Both Parents shall check their e-mail and texts at least once daily and shall respond to messages or other items needing attention (
switch requests) within 48 hours. If more time is needed to respond, the receiving parent shall acknowledge the message and provide a timeline in which a response shall be provided.
COMMUNICATION BETWEEN CO-PARENTS: OUR FAMILY WIZARD OR OTHER MUTUALLY AGREED UPON PARENTING COMMUNICATION APPLICATION

Parents shall communicate solely through Our Family Wizard or other mutually agreed upon parenting communication application. Both Parents shall sign up for Our Family Wizard or other mutually agreed upon parenting communication application within ten (10) days of the date the last party signs this Agreement and shall maintain an account with said program.

. Parents shall meet monthly to discuss the childrenâ€™s development and needs including education, health, well-being, extracurricular activities, scheduling issues, travel and any other issues pertaining to their child(ren). Conferences shall be on the first ____

insert day of the week] of each month unless mutually agreed to otherwise. Meetings may be via in-person, video conference or telephone calls, as mutually agreed by the Parents. This requirement for monthly conferences between Parents shall end upon each childâ€™s eighteenth (18th) birthday, or as mutually agreed by the Parents.

. Parents shall meet and confer twice annually by no later than ________ [insert date] and ________ [insert date] every year. Meetings may be via in-person, video conference or telephone calls, as mutually agreed by the Parents. This requirement for bi-annual conferences between Parents shall end upon each childâ€™s eighteenth (18th) birthday, or as mutually agreed by the Parents.

Parents shall meet and confer annually by no later than ________ [insert date] every year. Meetings may be via in-person, video conference or telephone calls, as mutually agreed by the Parents. This requirement for annual conferences between Parents shall end upon each childâ€™s eighteenth (18th) birthday, or as mutually agreed by the Parents.
COMMUNICATION BETWEEN CHILD(REN) AND NON-CUSTODIAL PARENT: UNLIMITED
During the regular parenting time schedule, the child may contact each parent whenever they wish.
COMMUNICATION BETWEEN CHILD(REN) AND NON-CUSTODIAL PARENT: SPECIFIC

During the regular parenting time schedule, Parent A may call the child between [insert time] and [insert time] when they are with Parent B and Parent B may call the child between [insert time] and [insert time] when they are with Parent A. Calls will normally be no more than 10 minutes.

Parents shall provide to the other Parent with updated telephone number(s), email address, and home address. Parents agree that if this contact information changes, they shall provide the new contact information to the other Parent immediately.
COMMUNICATION: SCHEDULING EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES FOR THE CHILD(REN)

. Both Parents understand that reasonable extracurricular activities are healthy and appropriate outlets for our Child(ren). Both Parents understand that selecting extracurricular activities for the Child(ren) is a legal custody decision.
Neither of us will schedule extra-curricular activities during the time the Child(ren) is to be living with or in the care of the other
The other Parent shall not unreasonably withhold their agreement.
COMMUNICATION: SELECTING EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES FOR THE CHILD(REN)

Each Parent may select and pay for one extra-curricular activity that occurs no more than once a week for each Child, and the other Parent shall be expected to take each Child to that activity and support the Childâ€™s participation during the time that the Child is in their care.
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): MONTHLY CHILD SUPPORT AMOUNT UNDER THE LAW
Each State has Child Support Guidelines used to calculate monthly child support. Each parent shall be bound by and follow the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act.
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): CHILD SUPPORT GUIDELINES AMOUNT WHEN PARENTS RESIDE IN THE SAME STATE
Child support shall be paid by Parent A/B to Parent B/A and calculated pursuant to the State child support guidelines worksheet.
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): CHILD SUPPORT GUIDELINES AMOUNT WHEN PARENTS RESIDE IN DIFFERENT STATES
shall be paid by Parent A/B to Parent B/A and calculated pursuant to the guidelines for child support in the ____ [insert State].
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): MUTUALLY AGREED UPON CHILD SUPPORT AMOUNT ALTERNATIVE

. Child Support shall be paid by Parent A/B to Parent B/A by agreement of the Parents in the amount of $______/per Child per month for a total monthly child support amount of $_______. Both Parents understand that child support is modifiable going forward and at any time either Parent may request that child support be calculated pursuant to their State guidelines and ordered to be paid pursuant to
Order for Income Withholding (or similar order) via the State Child Support Enforcement Agency.
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): NO AGREEMENT OF THE PARTIES RE MONTHLY CHILD SUPPORT AMOUNT AND/OR JURISDICTION

. Parents do not agree on the amount of Child Support to be paid and/or on which State should have jurisdiction to calculate child support under the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act. Parents agree to litigate the issue of child support through the Family Court and/or the State Child Support Enforcement Agency.

and timesharing with the Child(ren) impacts the calculation of child support. If the child support amount if going to be litigated through the Family Court or administratively through the State Child Support Enforcement Agency, Parents are hereby advised to seek independent legal counsel before making any agreements regarding physical custody and timesharing.
RT OF THE CHILD(REN): CHILD SUPPORT ACCOUNT ALTERNATIVE
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): DIRECT PAYMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): PAYMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT THROUGH THE STATE CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT AGENCY
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): HEALTH INSURANCE PREMIUM
. Parent A/B shall cover the Child(ren)â€™s health insurance premiums in the amount of $______ per month.
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): UNINSURED CO-PAYS FOR HEALTH-RELATED EXPENSES
. Parent A/B shall cover 100% of the Child(ren)â€™s uninsured co-pays for health-related expenses premiums in the amount of $______ per month.
. Parent A shall cover ____% and Parent B shall cover ____% of the Child(ren)â€™s uninsured co-pays for health-related expenses premiums in the amount of $______ per month.
. Each Parent shall cover up to $____ per Child per calendar year in uninsured co-pays for health-related expenses.

any Childâ€™s uninsured co-pays for health-related expenses paid by either parent exceeds $____ per calendar year, then Parent A shall cover ____% and Parent B shall cover ____% of the Child(ren)â€™s uninsured co-pays for health-related expenses premiums exceeding the threshold amount.
DEFINITION OF UNINSURED HEALTH-RELATED EXPENSES: RECOMMENDED BY PROVIDERS
. Uninsured health-related expenses shall include, without limitation, all medical, dental, vision, mental health, orthodontia,
and other health-related expenses for a Child recommended for a Child by the Childâ€™s relevant provider (Pediatrician, Dentist, Orthodontist, Therapist, Psychiatrist, etc.).
DEFINITION OF UNINSURED HEALTH-RELATED EXPENSES: MUTUAL AGREEMENT OF THE PARENTS
. Uninsured health-related expenses shall include, without limitation, all medical, dental, vision, mental health, orthodontia,
and other health-related expenses for a Child that both Parents mutually agree
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): EXTRACURRICULAR EXPENSES
. Parent A/B shall cover 100% of the Child(ren)â€™s extracurricular expenses.
Parent A shall cover ____% and Parent B shall cover ____% of the Child(ren)â€™s extracurricular expenses.
SELECTING EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES FOR THE CHILD(REN) PURSUANT TO 7.10 HEREINABOVE
. If the Parents have elected to separately select

and pay for one extra-curricular activity that occurs no more than once a week for each Child, then the other Parent shall be expected to take each Child to that activity and support the Childâ€™s participation during the time that the Child is in their care, pursuant to Paragraph 7.10 hereinabove. Each Parent shall pay for 100% of their selected extracurricular activity, which shall include supplies, uniforms, travel out-of-state, and other expenses required for the Child to participate
EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES MUST BE MUTUALLY AGREED UPON

. Parents shall only be responsible for paying for extracurricular activities that are mutually agreed upon by both Parents. Parents agree to consult and be guided by the Childâ€™s preferences in selecting mutually agreed upon extracurricular activities.
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): PRIVATE SCHOOL EXPENSES
. Parent A/B shall cover 100% of the Child(ren)â€™s private school expenses.
. Parent A shall cover ____% and Parent B shall cover ____% of the Child(ren)â€™s private school expenses.

. Private school expenses shall be defined to include all expenses related to a Childâ€™s attendance at a private school including, without limitation, application fees/costs, tuition, books, uniforms, school lunches, and before and/or after school care expenses.
. Either Parent may apply for a Child to attend private school but unless one parent has sole legal custody, both Parents must approve the enrollment of any Child in a private school.
. Parents shall reserve the issue of private school expenses.
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): POST-HIGH SCHOOL EDUCATION EXPENSES
. Parent A/B shall cover 100% of the Child(ren)â€™s post-high school education expenses.
. Parent A shall cover ____% and Parent B shall cover ____% of the Child(ren)â€™s post-high school education expenses.
SOLE RESPONSIBILITY AFTER FUNDS FROM ANY 529 ACCOUNTS HELD ON BEHALF OF A CHILD OR CHILD(REN), COVERDELL ACCOUNTS OR OTHER FUNDS EAR-MARKED TO PAY FOR A CHILDâ€™S POST-HIGH SCHOOL EDUCATION EXPENSES

. After funds from any 529 accounts held on behalf of a Child or Child(ren), Coverdell accounts or other funds ear-marked to pay for a Childâ€™s post-high school education expenses are expended, then Parent A/B shall cover 100% of the Child(ren)â€™s remaining post-high school education expenses.
SPLIT RESPONSIBILITY AFTER FUNDS FROM ANY 529 ACCOUNTS HELD ON BEHALF OF A CHILD OR CHILD(REN), COVERDELL ACCOUNTS OR OTHER FUNDS EAR-MARKED TO PAY FOR A CHILDâ€™S POST-HIGH SCHOOL EDUCATION EXPENSES

. After funds from any 529 accounts held on behalf of a Child or Child(ren), Coverdell accounts or other funds ear-marked to pay for a Childâ€™s post-high school education expenses are expended, then Parent A shall cover ____% and Parent B shall cover ____% of the Child(ren)â€™s remaining post-high school education expenses.
CAP ON PAYMENT BY EACH PARENT PER ACADEMIC SCHOOL YEAR

. The Child(ren)â€™s post-high school education expenses shall be paid such that Parent A shall cover ____% up to a cap of $____ amount per academic school year and Parent B shall cover ____% up to a cap of $____ amount per academic school year.
DEFINITION OF POST-HIGH SCHOOL EDUCATION EXPENSES

. Private school expenses shall be defined to include all expenses related to a Childâ€™s attendance at any post-high school educational institution (including vocational and trade schools), without limitation, application fees/costs, tuition, books, uniforms, school lunches, and before and/or after school care expenses.
. Either Parent may apply for a Child to attend a post-high school education institution (includes trade and vocational schools), but
the other Parent to be financially responsible, both Parents must approve the enrollment of any Child or Adult Child in a post-high school educational institution.
. Parents shall reserve the issue of post-high school educational school expenses.
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): CLAIMING THE CHILD(REN) AS A DEPENDENT FOR TAX PURPOSES
SOLE AUTHORITY TO CLAIM THE CHILD(REN
. Parent A/B shall be entitled to claim any Child(ren) as a dependent for tax purposes every year.
SPLIT AUTHORITY TO CLAIM THE CHILD(REN
. Parent A shall be entitled to claim ____
Childâ€™s Initials) as a dependent for tax purposes every year. Parent B shall be entitled to claim ____
Childâ€™s Initials) as a dependent for tax purposes every year.

. Parent A shall be entitled to claim ____
Childâ€™s Initials) as a dependent for tax purposes every year. Parent B shall be entitled to claim ____
Childâ€™s Initials) as a dependent for tax purposes every year. Once the older Child is no longer eligible to be claimed for tax purposes, then the Parents shall alternate claiming the younger Child.
ALTERNATE AUTHORITY TO CLAIM THE CHILD(REN
. Parent A shall be entitled to claim the Child(ren) as dependent(s) for tax purposes
in even years. Parent B shall be entitled to claim the Child(ren) as dependent(s) for tax purposes in odd years.
SUPPORT OF THE CHILD(REN): PROTOCOLS FOR REIMBURSEMENT OF CHILD-RELATED EXPENSES
TIMEFRAME FOR REIMBURSEMENT OF CHILD-RELATED EXPENSES
. Upon a request in writing (text or email is ok) from a Parent for reimbursement, the other Parent shall reimburse the requesting Parent within ____ days.
MONTHLY CALCULATION OF CHILD-RELATED EXPENSES AND REIMBURSEMENT
. Parents shall calculate child-related expenses and reimburse each other
QUARTERLY CALCULATION OF CHILD-RELATED EXPENSES AND REIMBURSEMENT
Parents shall calculate child-related expenses and reimburse each other on a quarterly basis.
ANNUAL CALCULATION OF CHILD-RELATED EXPENSES AND REIMBURSEMENT
Parents shall calculate child-related expenses and reimburse each other on an annual basis.
DOCUMENTATION REQUIRED FOR REIMBURSEMENT OF CHILD-RELATED EXPENSES
. A requesting Parent shall include written documentation proving the child-related expense
receive reimbursement from the other Parent.

. Parents shall use the following method to reimburse each other for child-related expenses: Check, Bank Account Transfer, Venmo, Our Family Wizard or other mutually agreed upon parenting expense tool or application, or __________________.
. Parents agree to engage______________________(name), or other mutually selected licensed mental health professional, as a Co-Parent Counselor to assist them in collaboratively
parenting the Child(ren). Both Parents shall continue in Co-Parent Counseling until clinically discharged or upon the mutual agreement of both Parents.

. Parents agree to engage______________________(name), or other mutually selected licensed mental health professional, as a Child-Focused Therapist for Child(ren). Both parents shall have access to the child therapist and shall participate in therapy and/or engage with the Child-Focused Therapist at the therapistâ€™s discretion. Parents shall alternate taking the Child(ren) to therapy. Parents agree that the Child(ren) shall continue in therapy as needed and upon the schedule recommended by the therapist with input from the Child(ren) until clinically discharged. If mutually agreed, parent may jointly select a new therapist for Child(ren). Unless they have sole legal custody of the Child(ren), neither Parent may unilaterally terminate child therapy without the other Parentâ€™s consent.
OTHER ISSUES: SOCIAL MEDIA BETWEEN PARENTS
. Neither Parent shall post any pictures of the other Parent on social media nor make any derogatory comment about the other Parent on social media.
OTHER ISSUES: SOCIAL MEDIA FOR CHILD(REN

. Parents agree that none of their Child(ren) shall have access to any social media platform until they reach thirteen (13) years of age, and thereafter both Parents shall monitor any Childâ€™s social media usage to ensure that it is safe and does not cause embarrassment to either Parent or the Child.
Parents agree that it is in their Child(ren)â€™s best interests that they both attend parent-teacher meetings together.
will each arrange our own separate parent-teacher meetings.
OTHER ISSUES: ONE PARENT TO ATTEND PARENT-TEACHER MEETINGS
Parent A/B will attend all parent-teacher meetings and will advise Parent B/A of the Child(ren)'s progress.
OTHER ISSUES: REPORT CARDS FOR THE CHILD(REN
. Both Parents will be provided with separate report cards for the Child(ren). Parents shall notify the school authorities to provide separate report cards.
OTHER ISSUES: JOINT ATTENDANCE AT SCHOOL AND EXTRACURRICULAR EVENTS
. Both Parents may attend school events and extra-curricular activities.
OTHER ISSUES: CUSTODIAL PARENT TO ATTEND SCHOOL AND EXTRACURRICULAR EVENTS
The Parent with whom the Child(ren) is/are residing at the time of the school event and extracurricular activity will be the sole Parent to attend these events.
OTHER ISSUES: ALTERNATE ATTENDANCE AT SCHOOL AND EXTRACURRICULAR EVENTS
. Parent shall alternate attending the Child(ren)â€™s school events and extracurricular activities.

Parent A/B will keep the original passport issued in the Child(ren)'s name, their social security card, birth certificate, and [insert any other relevant documents] at their home, and these documents will be made available to Parent B/A as needed. Both Parents shall have copies of
OTHER ISSUES: JOINT AUTHORITY TO CONSENT FOR PASSPORT
Parent A and Parent B must both consent for the purposes of a passport application for any Child.
OTHER ISSUES: SOLE AUTHORITY TO CONSENT FOR PASSPORT
Parent A/B can apply for the passport for a Child without the consent of Parent B/A.
OTHER ISSUES: NEW INTIMATE PARTNER PROTOCOLS (LESS DETAILED)

Both parents agree that they shall not introduce any of their minor children to a new significant other or intimate partner until (a) they have been in an intimate dating relationship for six (6) months or longer and (b) the other parent has been given an opportunity to meet that significant other/intimate partner first. Parents shall be guided by the childrenâ€™s best interests and conflict

minimization in determining a reasonable compromise on any issues arising from this provision. If parents cannot agree, they shall consult with and engage mutually acceptable therapist or other mental health professional informed and guided by their recommendations. Unless otherwise agreed upon in writing, neither parent shall be allowed to travel with the children and their significant other/intimate partner unless or until that parent has, in fact, married their new partner. This plan is subject to further review based on the best interests of the children and their observed reactions and behaviors throughout any introduction process.
OTHER ISSUES: NEW INTIMATE PARTNER PROTOCOLS (MORE DETAILED)
. Given that both parents will likely engage in new intimate partner relationships in the future, it is their intent that the childrenâ€™s well-being,
and stability remain the highest priority. Both parents agree to be respectful of one another and guided by the following concepts and protocols:

Take an honest look at the relationship. If you are just having fun enjoying a new personâ€™s company but know there is no long-term potential, it is probably best not to introduce the children to a new intimate partner.

Your relationship shall be well-established and stable prior to initiating these new intimate partner protocols. The Parents shall discuss the appropriate timing and circumstances in which the children should formally meet a new intimate partner and be told that the nature of the relationship is romantic. It is understood that the children may

the new intimate partner in advance, but the actual introduction of this new person as a romantic relationship shall not occur before the Parents are able to discuss the circumstances in co-parent counseling.
The other parent shall be notified in advance of the children and given the opportunity to meet the new intimate partner prior to the
children being introduced to the new intimate partner and told the nature of the relationship is romantic.

Parents shall use best practices and judgment when engaging in appropriate public displays of affection with their new intimate partner in front of any of the children. Parents shall further check in with the children to gauge their comfort with the new intimate partner. This may be accomplished within a therapeutic process (
check-ins by the co-parent counselor with the child therapist as discussed below).
, shall refrain from disciplining the children unless there is an agreement between both parents otherwise
The Parents shall discuss age-appropriate discipline options for the children.

In the event there are any problems related to the new intimate partner or these protocols, the Parents shall engage a mental health professional such as a co-parent counselor or family therapist who may also confer with the child therapist to ensure the childrenâ€™s well-being, comfort and stability remain the highest priority.

. If there is any disagreement related to this Agreement or any Child-related issues, both Parents agree that they shall engage a mutually selected mediator to help them resolve the issue(s) prior to filing a motion for relief with the Family Court.

. Except as otherwise limited by Statute, Court Rule or case authority, the Family Court shall have the ongoing authority and personal and subject matter jurisdiction to make any other just and equitable orders which may be necessary to enforce the intended agreement and specific provisions set forth herein.
. A Parent who fails to comply with this
Co-Parenting Plan: Agreement Regarding Child Custody, Timesharing, and Support
shall be liable to the other Parent for all reasonable legal fees and costs incurred and reasonable damages suffered by the other Parent

noncompliance. The Family Court shall have continuing jurisdiction over the parents and their property to enforce and implement the provisions of the Agreement, to the extent permitted by applicable statutory authority, court rule and/or case law.
. Each Parent acknowledges that they have voluntarily executed this
Co-Parenting Plan: Agreement Regarding Child Custody, Timesharing, and Support

with sufficient knowledge of the facts and the law, and that it is fair and reasonable. Both Parents have been advised to seek independent legal counsel regarding these and all other matters contained herein.
